Constructor & Destructor Documentation

CWidget::CWidget ( ) [inline]
 

Constructs a CWidget object that is not connected to a Photon widget. It cannot be used before a call to setWidgetPointer(), \ createFromDataBase() or createTreeFromDataBase() \

Definition at line 62 of file CWidget.hpp.

CWidget::CWidget ( PtWidget_t * widgetPointer ) [inline]
 

Definition at line 68 of file CWidget.hpp.

CWidget::CWidget ( ApDBase_t * widgetDataBase,
char * widgetName ) [inline]
 

Constructs a CWidget object and creates its Photon widget and children widgets (the whole widget tree) according to information of a widget named <widgetName> from a widget data base. Parent is the last container widget created

Definition at line 74 of file CWidget.hpp.

CWidget::CWidget ( char * widgetName,
CWidget * root = 0 ) [inline]
 

Constructs a CWidget object and connects it to a Photon widget that is in a widget tree with the root <root> and has the "user data" resource set to the string <widgetName>

Definition at line 82 of file CWidget.hpp.

CWidget::~CWidget ( ) [virtual]
 

Destructs the CWidget object. The destructor is usually called automatically when the parent widget is destroyed. If it is called explicitely, the connected Photon widget is destroyed.

Sets the pointer to the PtWidget structure

int CWidget::isWidget ( PtWidget_t * widget )
 

Returns 1 if the widget pointer belongs to the QWidgets++ widget object, 0 otherwise

CWidget * CWidget::getWidgetObject ( PtWidget_t * widget ) [static]
 

Returns the QWidgets++ widget object related to a widget pointer This function only works for widgets created by QWidgets++, and if widget backpointers are enabled (See setWidgetBackpointersOn())

int CWidget::createFromDataBase ( ApDBase_t * widgetDataBase,
char * widgetName )
 

Creates a widget from the information stored in a widget database The name of the widget created in PhAB has to match <widgetName>

int CWidget::createTreeFromDataBase ( ApDBase_t * widgetDataBase,
char * widgetName )
 

Creates a widget and all children (the complete tree) from the information stored in a widget database. The name of the root widget in PhAB has to match <widgetName>

Referenced by CWidget().

int CWidget::linkDataBaseWidget ( char * widgetName,
CWidget * root = 0 )
 

Links the widget to a widget already created from a widget data base (by using createFromDataBase or createTreeFromDataBase) <widgetName> has to match the name specified in the "User Data" resource of the widget. <root> specifies the root of the widget tree. Leaving this parameter out will search all widgets

Referenced by CWidget().

Returns the class name of a widget specified by a PtWidget_t pointer

void CWidget::printWidgetTree ( ostream & stream = cout )
 

Prints the widget tree, starting at the current widget (this) Prints it to the specified stream

void CWidget::setWidgetBackpointersOn ( ) [inline, static]
 

Definition at line 157 of file CWidget.hpp.

void CWidget::setWidgetBackpointersOff ( ) [inline, static]
 

Definition at line 158 of file CWidget.hpp.

int CWidget::isWidgetBackpointers ( ) [inline, static]
 

Enables or disables the creation of widget backpointers while creating new widgets. These backpointers allow to determine the QWidgets++ object from the PtWidget_t pointer and use the user data resource of the widget. By default, backpointers are off one might not want to use this feature because the user data resource is used for other purposes or the amount of dynamic memory should be decreased. If backpointers are enabled, the function getWidgetObject() can be used for widgets created by QWidgets++

Definition at line 159 of file CWidget.hpp.

int CWidget::create ( PtWidgetClassRef_t * className,
CWidget * parent )
 

Creates the widget as a child of parent Returns: 0 success, -1 error

int CWidget::create ( PtWidgetClassRef_t * className,
CWidget * parent,
int x,
int y,
int width = 0,
int height = 0 )
 

Creates the widget as a child of parent of a certain extent Returns: 0 success, -1 error

int CWidget::realize ( )
 

This function initializes a widget and its children, making them visible to the user and possibly making them interactive. Returns: 0 success, -1 error

int CWidget::unrealize ( )
 

This function unrealizes the specified widget and all its children: the widgets are removed from the display, and the widget engine will no longer invoke their callbacks. Unrealized widgets still exist in the widget hierarchy and can be realized again. Returns: 0 success, -1 error

void CWidget::addCallback ( unsigned long callbackType,
PtCallbackF_t callbackFunction,
void * data = 0 )
 

Adds a callback function to the widget

void CWidget::addCallbackAsFirstCallback ( unsigned long callbackType,
PtCallbackF_t callbackFunction,
void * data = 0 )
 

Adds a callback function to the widget and makes sure it is the first callback in the list (Called first). This is useful for CMenu widgets. All buttons in a menu (CMenu) usually contain the unrealization of the menu as the first callback, which is not always useful

int CWidget::setResource ( int type,
int value,
int len = 0 )
 

int CWidget::setResource ( int type,
unsigned int value,
int len = 0 )
 

int CWidget::setResource ( int type,
void * value,
int len = 0 )
 

Sets a resource of the widget. Parameters as in PtSetArg The type argument contains the resource manifest and value contains the value of the argument being passed. The meaning of len varies, please see PtSetArg Returns: 0 success, -1 error

int CWidget::getResource ( int type,
void * value,
int len = 0 )
 

Gets a resource of the widget

int CWidget::getResource ( int type )
 

Gets a number resource of the widget and returns it

int CWidget::disable ( )
 

Disables widget by dimming it and blocking Photon events

int CWidget::enable ( )
 

Reverse operation to disable

int CWidget::isDisabled ( )
 

Returns nonzero value if the control is disabled

int CWidget::isEnabled ( )
 

Returns nonzero value if the control is enabled

int CWidget::damage ( )
 

This function adds the specified widget's extent to the damage list of the widget's first window parent. This effectively marks the widget as being damaged so that it will be redrawn. The widget library takes care of updating widgets whenever resources are modified. So you don't normally use this function unless you're mixing Pg*() calls with widget calls, and want a widget to redraw and repair itself directly.

int CWidget::setParent ( CWidget * parent )
 

Changes the widget to a new parent

void CWidget::calculateExtent ( )
 

This function forces the specified widget to calculate its extent. You can use this function to force PtGroup to redo the layout of its children.

void CWidget::familyCalculateExtent ( )
 

This function forces the specified widget and all children to calculate its extent.

int CWidget::moveToFront ( )
 

Moves the widget in front of all its brothers. All of the widgets children are moved too.

Reimplemented in CWindow.

int CWidget::moveToBack ( )
 

Moves the widget behind all its brothers. All of the widgets children are moved too.

Reimplemented in CWindow.

CWidget * CWidget::walkThroughTree ( int & walkThroughMode,
CWidget * widget )
 

Walks through the widget tree with this as the root. Initialize walkThroughMode to Pt_TRAVERSE_START Then use feed back returned widget pointer to function. Returns zero when traverse is done

int CWidget::isClass ( PtWidgetClassRef_t * widgetClass )
 

Determines whether the widget is of the specified widget class, returns 1 if it is, otherwise returns zero

int CWidget::isClassMember ( PtWidgetClassRef_t * widgetClass )
 

Determines whether or not the specified widget is a member of the specified widget class

CWidget * CWidget::getParentByClass ( PtWidgetClassRef_t * parentClass )
 

Tries to find the nearest parent widget in the hierarchy that matches the specified parent class

CWidget * CWidget::getParent ( )
 

Returns the parent widget, 0, if the widget is the top of the hierarchy

int CWidget::getChildType ( CWidget * child )
 

Determines the relationship to the widget <child> Returns: Pt_IMMEDIATE_CHILD immediate child Pt_SUBORDINATES_CHILD child of a procreated child Pt_FALSE no child

CWidget * CWidget::getBrotherInFront ( )
 

Returns a pointer to the brother in front of this widget. Returns zero if there is no brother in front

CWidget * CWidget::getBrotherBehind ( )
 

Returns a pointer to the brother behind the widget. Returns zero if there is no brother behind

CWidget * CWidget::getChildBack ( )
 

Returns a pointer to the child that' farthest back of the widget. If the widget doesn't have any children, returns zero

CWidget * CWidget::getChildFront ( )
 

Returns a pointer to the child at the very front of the widget. If the widget doesn't have any children, returns zero

int CWidget::getExtentWidth ( )
 

int CWidget::getExtentHeight ( )
 

Gets the extent (outside size) of the widget A widget's extent isn't calculated until the widget is either realized or forced to calculate the extent by a caculateExtent() call. Calling a widget's extent is calculated returns a zero extent

int CWidget::setBitmapCursor ( PhCursorDef_t * cursor )
 

Defines bitmaps for the cursor

int CWidget::setBorderWidth ( int borderWidth )
 

Sets the thickness of the widget's border. borderWidth must not exceed 15 pixels.

int CWidget::setCursorColor ( PgColor_t cursorColor )
 

The color of the pointer when it's inside the widget.

int CWidget::setData ( void * data )
 

This resource is used only for custom widgets. For more information, see the Building Custom Widgets guide.

int CWidget::setConsumeEventsOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setConsumeEventsOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isConsumeEvents ( )
 

If on, widget will consume any event encountered whether or not an action was performed as a result of that event.

int CWidget::setInternalHelpOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setInternalHelpOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isInternalHelp ( )
 

On: Help information for the widget is displayed in a balloon, not in the Helpviewer. See the chapter on Context-Sensitive Help in the Programmer's Guide.

int CWidget::setPropagateDamageToParentOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setPropagateDamageToParentOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isPropagateDamageToParent ( )
 

If the widget is damaged for any reason, propagate the damage to its parent.

int CWidget::setSpecialCallbacksActiveOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setSpecialCallbacksActiveOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isSpecialCallbacksActive ( )
 

For a few widgets, setting resources will cause relevant callbacks to be invoked if this feature is set. Otherwise callbacks are not invoked as a result of setting resources. If a callback relies on this flag, its description says so explicitly.

int CWidget::enableAllMouseButtons ( )
 

int CWidget::enableOnlyLeftMouseButton ( )
 

int CWidget::areAllMouseButtonsEnabled ( )
 

Specifies which mouse buttons can activate the widget Default is only the left button

int CWidget::setAutohighlightOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setAutohighlightOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isAutohighlight ( )
 

If on, causes the widget to highlight and get focus when the cursor enters its extent, and to unhighlight and lose focus when the cursor leaves.

int CWidget::setBlockingOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setBlockingOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isBlocking ( )
 

Blocking prevents the widget and all its non-window-class children from interacting with Photon events.

int CWidget::isClear ( )
 

When on, clips the corners of the rectangle that highlights the widget.

int CWidget::isDamaged ( )
 

Returns value > 0 if the widget requires repair

int CWidget::isDamageFamily ( )
 

Returns value > 0 if the widget and all its children will be repaired

int CWidget::setDelayRealizeOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setDelayRealizeOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isDelayRealize ( )
 

If on, prevents widget from becoming realized unless it's explicitly realized with CWidget::realize()

int CWidget::isDestroyed ( )
 

Returns value > 0 if the widget is marked for destruction

int CWidget::setEtchHighlightOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setEtchHighlightOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isEtchHighlight ( )
 

If on, highlights the widget with an etched-line style (normally, a beveled rectangle is used).

int CWidget::setClipHighlightOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setClipHighlightOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isClipHighlight ( )
 

If on, clips the corners of the rectangle that highlights the widget.

int CWidget::setFreeMemoryOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setFreeMemoryOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isFreeMemory ( )
 

If on, indicates that the widget may free memory associated with any of its pointers. For example, if this flag is set, a CLabel widget with an image structure will free the image memory as well as its own image structure.

int CWidget::setFocusRenderOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setFocusRenderOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isFocusRender ( )
 

Draws a dotted line around the widget when it gets focus.

int CWidget::setGetsFocusOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setGetsFocusOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isGetsFocus ( )
 

If on, allows the widget to be granted focus when appropriate.

int CWidget::setGhostOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setGhostOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isGhost ( )
 

If on, the widget is dimmed. Setting this flag doesn't affect the widget's behavior, just its appearance.

int CWidget::setHighlightOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setHighlightOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isHighlighted ( )
 

Highlights the widget with a beveled or etched rectangle.

int CWidget::isOnHold ( )
 

A returnvalue > 0 indicates that the widget is on hold, e.g. repairs to it and its children are prevented

int CWidget::setMenuableOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setMenuableOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isMenuable ( )
 

If on, the widget will respond to right mouse clicks (i.e. enables CBasic's menu callback

int CWidget::setTypeMenuButtonOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setTypeMenuButtonOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isTypeMenuButton ( )
 

If on, indicates that the widget is a menu item

int CWidget::isObscured ( )
 

Returns value > 0, if the widget's brothers completely obscure it from view.

int CWidget::isOpaque ( )
 

Returns value > 0, if the widget completely obscures everything behind it and inside its extent.

int CWidget::isProcreated ( )
 

Returns value > 0, if the widget is a procreated child of a compound widget.

int CWidget::isRealized ( )
 

Returns value > 0, if the widget is realized

int CWidget::isRealizing ( )
 

Returns value > 0, if the widget is in the process of being realized

int CWidget::setRegionOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setRegionOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isRegion ( )
 

If on, forces the widget to have a region

int CWidget::setSelectableOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setSelectableOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isSelectable ( )
 

If on, the user can select (repeat, arm, disarm, and activate) this widget. The widget will usually provide visual feedback when selected.

int CWidget::setRedrawOnSelectOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setRedrawOnSelectOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isRedrawOnSelect ( )
 

If off, the widget won't change its appearance when set or unset. This is meaningful only when the widget is selectable.

int CWidget::setSelectedOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setSelectedOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isSelected ( )
 

If on, indicates that the widget is in a "set" state. Generally, this indicates that the widget has been selected.

int CWidget::setToggleOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setToggleOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isToggle ( )
 

If on, indicates that pressing the mouse button on this widget will cause it to toggle between being set and unset. Normally, selectable widgets act as push buttons when you release the button.

int CWidget::isRebuilt ( )
 

Returns a value > 0 if the widget will be rebuilt (re-realized) when the widget engine is finished applying resource changes.

int CWidget::isResized ( )
 

Returns a value > 0, if the widget will be resized when the widget engine is finished applying resource changes.

int CWidget::setHelpTopic ( char * helpTopic )
 

Either the topic position within the HTML help file if setInternalHelpOff() was called, or the help information to be displayed, if setInternalHelpOn() was called

int CWidget::setResizeXNever ( )
 

int CWidget::setResizeXAlways ( )
 

int CWidget::setResizeXAsRequired ( )
 

Sets the resize policy in x direction

int CWidget::setResizeXInitialOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setResizeXInitialOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isResizeXInitial ( )
 

If on, the x resize policy will be applied only once each time the widget is realized. This bit is meaningful only in concert with ...ALWAYS or ...AS_REQUIRED.

int CWidget::setResizeYNever ( )
 

int CWidget::setResizeYAlways ( )
 

int CWidget::setResizeYAsRequired ( )
 

Sets the resize policy in y direction

int CWidget::setResizeYInitialOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setResizeYInitialOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isResizeYInitial ( )
 

If on, the y resize policy will be applied only once each time the widget is realized. This bit is meaningful only in concert with ...ALWAYS or ...AS_REQUIRED.

int CWidget::setResizeXYNever ( )
 

int CWidget::setResizeXYAlways ( )
 

int CWidget::setResizeXYAsRequired ( )
 

Sets the same resize policy in x and y direction

int CWidget::setResizeXYInitialOn ( )
 

int CWidget::setResizeXYInitialOff ( )
 

int CWidget::isResizeXYInitial ( )
 

If on, the x and y resize policy will be applied only once each time the widget is realized. This bit is meaningful only in concert with ...ALWAYS or ...AS_REQUIRED.

void CWidget::addBlockedCallback ( PtCallbackF_t callbackFunction,
void * data = 0 )
 

Adds a callback that the widget invokes whenever it must ignore an event due to being blocked.

void CWidget::addDestroyedCallback ( PtCallbackF_t callbackFunction,
void * data = 0 )
 

Adds a callback that the widget invokes when it is destroyed. You'll find this resource useful for cleaning up variables or memory associated with the widget.

void CWidget::addHotkeyCallback ( int keySymCap,
int keySymMods,
int flags,
PtCallbackF_t callbackFunction = 0,
void * data = 0 )
 

A list of PtHotkeyCallback_t structures. If the widget receives a key event that matches a structure's key cap and key mods, the widget will call the function specified in that structure. If a function isn't specified, the widget invokes its activate callback list.

void CWidget::addEventHandler ( unsigned long eventMask,
PtCallbackF_t callbackFunction,
void * data = 0 )
 

Adds a callback that the widget invokes if the raw event it receives matches the event mask provided in the PtRawCallback_t structure.

void CWidget::addRealizedCallback ( PtCallbackF_t callbackFunction,
void * data = 0 )
 

Adds a callback that the widget invokes whenever it is realized.

void CWidget::addUnrealizedCallback ( PtCallbackF_t callbackFunction,
void * data = 0 )
 

Adds a callback that the widget invokes whenever it is unrealized.

int CWidget::setUserData ( void * userData,
int len ) [protected]
 

Attaches an arbitrary user-defined data structure to the widget. The data block beginning with <userData> of the length <len> is copied to an internal storage space of the widget

int CWidget::setUserData ( void * userDataPtr ) [protected]
 

Attaches a void * as user-defined data to the widget. Only the value of the pointer is stored in the widget

void * CWidget::getUserData ( ) [protected]
 

Returns the pointer to the user data
